pros: Busy and coworkers are great to work with

review_title: Hca Needs to wake up to their overworked and overburdened doctors and nurses to create better patient care.
pros: The hospital is beautiful. Its  located in beautiful Portsmouth New Hampshire.
cons: I worked days on a very busy MedSurg floor at Portsmouth hospital. We were told time and time again that there are no ratios anymore for nurses and patients. And they kept raising The amount of patients we would have. When I left the nurses were receiving eight and nine patients. It is an ungodly amount of work, it is not safe for patients. .  As a nurse you want to provide high patient level care, that’s why we do this. But when the company you work for is all about making money and increasing the patient loads so that they can turn a profit..Everybody loses., the supervisors couldn’t help ..we would beg for help. I was a preceptor on the floor to many young nurses, I was trying to teach them to be a good nurse and to advocate for your patients. It was a continuous uphill battle to get Overworked doctors to respond to the needs of the patients. HCA is a multimillion dollar corporation and they should be ashamed of themselves. It’s a beautiful hospital which can be deceiving. They train their staff well to hide the stress that they are experiencing.

review_title: Would not recommend this place to anyone
pros: the only pro is the paycheck
cons:
Complete lack of support and misinformation from management
poor leadership
unsafe patient ratios

job_title: Physical Therapist PRN in Portsmouth, NH
pros: Very cohesive work environment. The co-workers in the rehab department are passionate about their job, caring, and hard working.
cons: Occasionally will be called out

job_title: Operating Room Assistant in Portsmouth, NH
pros: Being able to experience a large corporation
cons: The fact that it is run as a large corporation

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Gloucester, MA
pros: Good pay, nice area, moderate size
cons: Short staff, For profit company

review_title: Teamwork was the most important and greatest experiences.
pros: Everyone is respectable towards each other. We always ask questions and try to figure what the best solution is together. We as a team help each other out by taken care of the co-workers data information about their patient so that part is finished. Sometimes the department can get busy-answering phones,speaking to doctors and answering any questions the families or patients have about there procedure. Management was nice and tried to work with you on certain aspects.
cons:
Sometimes the communication between management and employees was not achieveable.
There was no advancement and if there was an open shift available because someone left you hardly had the chance to be chosen.

pros: Dedicated group of employees, beautiful campus. Plenty of opportunities for newly graduated nurses seeking employment. Hospital managed by a large corporation.
cons: Ancillary staff gets treated like social pariahs, and the lower you are on the totem pole your opinion matters all the less.  Company claims to be a patient centered hospital, but the decisions that get made by management prove that money is their priority. Opportunities for advancement are almost non-existent.

pros:
If you're a doctor or nurse (or upper management!) you'll be treated and paid fairly well.
The majority of the staff is competent and caring.
cons:
Management seems to be exclusively composed of rejects from the rest of HCA.
A little joke:  
Q: How was copper wire invented? 
A: Two HCA execs fighting over a penny.

On the patient care side, if you're not a doctor or nurse, you DO. NOT. MATTER. 
You will be underpaid, understaffed, and your needs will be ignored.
Equipment choices will be made for you by people hundreds of miles away, with no experience in the field.
Dictates are handed down from regional headquarters in Virginia, by people who know nothing about specifics of the hospital or market, and care even less.  

Pay is crap.  You’ll make (significantly) more starting at Dunkin Donuts than you will as entry-level staff at PRH.

Benefits are mediocre at best, especially for a huge, extremely profitable hospital chain.  You must use PRH affiliates for everything, unless maybe the ER doc is out of network then you’ll get hit with the full bill.

Human resources is broken.  3 months from application to starting is expected.
Management will make the right noises and say they'll get people hired, then six months later you'll be wondering why the entire department is still working 12 days in a row.

I could go on, but you get the idea.

review_title: Portsmouth Hospital had been a great place for me to work.
job_title: Service Line Director in Portsmouth, NH
pros: A culture of continued improvement and staff engagement. The facility is always looking for areas of improvement and takes in opportunities head on with transparency. The senior leadership team is engaged in continual improvement and engagement in the community. There has been opportunity for career growth and development available and the hospital is on the cutting edge for treatment and therapy of many service lines.
cons: Part of ensuring continued improvement is close management of resources. Recruiting of talented clinicians had been difficult to support growth and improvement.

review_title: Night Pharmacy services in a 200 bed acute care inpatient Hospital with a 20 bed ICU
pros: Learned a lot of new medication therapies and new medicaiton techniques
cons: Shift change was potentially difficult as the evening shift was trying to get out on time but that was often not possible due to multiple complex patients with complicated medication issues

pros: Engaged administrators, great staff, creative, good opportunities , easy to become involved in improvements and process change

pros: (Was employed there prior to  above date) dedicated PT, OT  & SLT practitioners. Fun group to work with.

pros: Proximity to my house I guess
cons: I left at will because there was absolutely no leadership support, staff morale made coming to work difficult, the company is so money oriented that patient safety was always second to profit. My license always felt at risk. I am much happier now at a nearby hospital without a doubt.
